Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project - Upgrade Physics Lab Technology Infrastructure and Develop Supplemental Instruction and Summer undergraduate research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. Florida Memorial University will implement a Targeted Infusion Project entitled: Physics Laboratory Technology Infrastructure Enhancement and Summer Undergraduate Research. This project involves the development of pedagogical methodologies for providing instruction in physics. The aim is to engage students in an interactive learning process using digital media to stimulate learning and comprehension. This project will aid in the recruitment, retention, and preparation for graduate school and the workforce of physics, chemistry, biology and mathematics majors at the university.

Through this project, the teaching and learning process moves from the traditional method of instruction to a blended method of computer-based, web and internet assisted instruction. Specific objectives include: upgrading the physics laboratory; establishing a faculty and student led learning community via supplemental instruction; providing tutoring sessions in Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics and Physics; and providing intensive problem solving sessions for Algebra, Pre-calculus, Trigonometry, Chemistry and Physics courses. Summer research experiences will enable undergraduate students to develop critical thinking skills and work with a mentor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Outcomes of the NSF (HBCU-UP, TIP) HRD-1438834 Grant Project

The main goals of the grant program were to increase the retention, progression and graduation rates by providing the technology-based academic program of support for the students majoring in the STEM disciplines; and develop a program in which the described activities will enable students to improve their critical thinking skills through early supplemental instruction, mentoring and research exposure. Below are the outcomes of the three  year grant project for  the various activities including the physics laboratory technology infrastructure; the undergraduate research; the divisional seminars; and the student tutoring and supplemental instruction:

a. Physics Laboratory Technology Infrastructure

Under this grant, we have upgraded the physics laboratory infrastructure with Vernier sensors, interfaces, and the new Pasco 850 Comprehensive Physics System which can be used to conduct over 80 classic experiments in Physics.  As a part of our educational technologies, the New Pasco 850 System, Vernier sensors and interfaces are extensively used to conduct many classic experiments to motivate and engage students during the physics lecture and laboratory activities, they were able to familiarize themselves with experimental design and the operation of laboratory equipment using sensors, interfaces, PASCO Capstone [1] and Vernier software [2], PASCO Capstone and Vernier electronic workbooks with step-by-step instructions, sample data , theory, experiment set-up, procedure, data analysis and questions designed to get the students to think about their results. The physics with technology assisted experiments has a positive impact [3] on the student learning and the program evaluation [3; 4] showed a strong progress in the student academic performance in every level of our physics course benchmarks.

b. Undergraduate Research Activities

We were able to recruit and support twelve students for our summer undergraduate research activities, and a total of 36 students have been supported during the grant period (2014-2017). Drs. Huisso (PI), Tamalis (Co-PI), Stiffin (Co-PI) and Sherman (Co-PI) have served as mentors,  and have organized a follow-up research program activities during each academic year by preparing and nurturing the students for the Florida Memorial University Annual Research Experiential Learning and Performing Arts Day (RELPAD), and for the regional research conferences and meetings. The students have successfully presented their preliminary and final research results at the FMU RELPAD, and some of the student abstracts have been accepted for the "2017 Emerging Researchers National” (ERN) Conference in STEM in Washington DC (3/2-3/3/ 2017), and for the Life Sciences of South Florida Symposium (April 8, 2017) where they have successfully presented their findings. The students were able to familiarize with STEM related research activities such as literature search, designing of experiments, the operation of laboratory equipment, the use of proper controls, analysis of data, and scientific writing; they helped disseminate and educate the student body at Florida Memorial University about their research results. Through the research experience and seminar activities, we were able to place, during the grant  three year period, more than 25 students into summer research internships of various institutions. The grant program evaluation [3] showed that. the students’ participation in research cemented in them an unwavering desire[4] to pursue advanced degrees  in STEM areas.The student research presentation pictures are attached.

 c. Divisional Research Seminars 

As a part of the grant activities, we have organized many Seminar Series to inform and expose our students to research activities of faculty members from FIU and other Research Institutions. We would like to thank Dr. Moon (FIU) for his sincere collaboration, and all the guest speakers for their excellent presentations; they have truly and greatly impressed, engaged and motivated our students in their research and internship activities. The students gained [4] an important appreciation and interest for the research seminars as a method of seeking internships. Through these research seminars, and with the help of our guest speakers, more than 25 students have been placed into summer  research internships of various institutions during the grant period (2014-2017).  The seminar  presentation pictures of Dr. Hutcheson, one of our many guest speakers from FIU, are attached.

d. Student Tutoring and Supplemental Instruction

We have provided peer-to-peer tutors and mentors, faculty advisors and research facilitators to increase retention, progression and graduation rates in the STEM fields. Under the grant, four students in pre-engineering and chemistry programs with a strong background in calculus, multivariable, differential equation, physics and chemistry have been recruited for  tutoring activities. They have helped the students with their homework assignments, class projects and laboratory reports. They have provided them with an important academic support [4] of intensive problem solving skills. Faculty  have an “open door" policy for their office hours often used for a supplemental instruction.
